stem: For each client, determine the appropriate triage category based on the provided assessment data from a mass casualty event.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
08:00 Report from scene. Multiple casualties reported following a building collapse. Resources stretched thin. Prioritize based on START triage principles.

08:05 Client A: ~30 y.o. female, RR 32, radial pulse present, able to follow simple commands. Obvious femur fracture noted.

08:10 Client B: ~60 y.o. male, RR 10, weak carotid pulse only, unresponsive to verbal stimuli. GCS 6.

08:15 Client C: ~20 y.o. male, RR 24, radial pulse present, confused and agitated. Multiple superficial lacerations.

08:20 Client D: ~70 y.o. female, no respirations after repositioning airway, no palpable pulse. 

08:25 Client E: ~45 y.o. male, RR 16, radial pulse present, reports severe abdominal pain, but hemodynamically stable with pale cool skin. Possible internal bleeding suspected.

tabs.content:
Client A: Obvious deformity to the right femur, + distal pulses, skin intact.

Client B: Shallow respirations, pinpoint pupils, unresponsive to pain.

Client C: Multiple superficial lacerations to arms and face, anxious, oriented to person only.

Client D: No spontaneous respirations after repositioning the airway. No carotid pulse palpable.

Client E: Complaining of severe abdominal pain, abdomen is rigid and tender to palpation. Skin is pale and cool.

rows.text: Client A: ~30 y.o. female, RR 32, radial pulse present, able to follow simple commands. Obvious femur fracture noted.
Client B: ~60 y.o. male, RR 10, weak carotid pulse only, unresponsive to verbal stimuli. GCS 6.
Client C: ~20 y.o. male, RR 24, radial pulse present, confused and agitated. Multiple superficial lacerations.
Client D: ~70 y.o. female, no respirations after repositioning airway, no palpable pulse.
Client E: ~45 y.o. male, RR 16, radial pulse present, reports severe abdominal pain, but hemodynamically stable with pale cool skin. Possible internal bleeding suspected.

rationale.correct: START triage categorizes patients based on RPM (Respiration, Perfusion, Mental Status). RED: Client A has RR > 30, indicating an immediate threat. Client E presents with signs of possible internal bleeding and requires immediate intervention. BLACK: Clients B & D are deceased or have injuries incompatible with life, given limited resources.
rationale.incorrect: YELLOW: Used for patients who are stable but require observation and later re-triage. GREEN: Used for the 'walking wounded' who can assist in their own care. Assigning the wrong color can delay treatment and potentially lead to negative outcomes.

answerBreakdown.text: Client A: ~30 y.o. female, RR 32, radial pulse present, able to follow simple commands. Obvious femur fracture noted.
answerBreakdown.rationale: The respiratory rate >30 qualifies this client for immediate (RED) triage. Even though they are able to follow commands, the elevated respiratory rate indicates respiratory distress and the need for immediate intervention.

answerBreakdown.text: Client B: ~60 y.o. male, RR 10, weak carotid pulse only, unresponsive to verbal stimuli. GCS 6.
answerBreakdown.rationale: With a GCS of 6, weak pulse, and being unresponsive, this client is categorized as expectant (BLACK). Resources should be directed to those with a higher chance of survival.

answerBreakdown.text: Client C: ~20 y.o. male, RR 24, radial pulse present, confused and agitated. Multiple superficial lacerations.
answerBreakdown.rationale: This client is confused but breathing and has a pulse, categorizing them as delayed (YELLOW). They require medical attention but not immediately.

answerBreakdown.text: Client D: ~70 y.o. female, no respirations after repositioning airway, no palpable pulse.
answerBreakdown.rationale: Having no respirations after airway repositioning and no pulse categorizes this client as expectant (BLACK). Resuscitation efforts would not be beneficial in a mass casualty situation with limited resources.

answerBreakdown.text: Client E: ~45 y.o. male, RR 16, radial pulse present, reports severe abdominal pain, but hemodynamically stable with pale cool skin. Possible internal bleeding suspected.
answerBreakdown.rationale: While the client is hemodynamically stable for now, the severe abdominal pain and signs of possible internal bleeding make this client an immediate priority (RED). Internal bleeding can quickly lead to shock and death.

clinicalPearls: Remember RPM (Respirations, Perfusion, Mental Status) when triaging during a mass casualty event.
A respiratory rate over 30 is an immediate indication for RED triage.
Patients who are not breathing after airway repositioning are categorized as expectant (BLACK) in a mass casualty situation.

questionTrap.trap: Students often miscategorize patients with fractures as immediate (RED), but if the patient is hemodynamically stable and breathing adequately, they are usually YELLOW.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Focus on the ABCs and signs of shock when determining triage category. Isolated fractures are usually not immediately life-threatening.
